maml:description.maml:para: Backup Eventlogs from remote computer
This function copies event log files from a remote computer to a backup location.

maml:Description.maml:para: The NetBIOS name of the computer to connect to.
The path to the logs you wish to backup. The default logpath "C:\Windows\system32\winevt\Logs" is used if left blank.
The location to copy the logs to.
The location to copy the logs to.
The NetBIOS name of the computer to connect to.
The path to the logs you wish to backup. The default logpath "C:\Windows\system32\winevt\Logs" is used if left blank.

maml:alert.maml:para: May need to be a user with rights to access various logs, such as security on remote computer.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Backup-EventLogs -ComputerName dc1

maml:description.maml:para: Connect to one or more computers over RDP

To securely cache login credentials, you can use the command line utility cmdkey.exe. With this utility, you can save a username and a password for a given remote connection. Windows will then securely cache the information and automatically use it when needed.

maml:Description.maml:para: The hostname or IP address of the computer to connect to
A credential object that contains a valid username and password for the remote computer
The hostname or IP address of the computer to connect to
A credential object that contains a valid username and password for the remote computer

maml:alert.maml:para: FunctionName : Connect-RDP Created by : jspatton Date Coded : 06/23/2014 08:48:25

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Connect-Rdp -ComputerName Server-01 -Credential Company.com\Administrator

dev:remarks.maml:para: The basic syntax showing a connection to a single machine

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Connect-Rdp -ComputerName Server-01, 192.168.1.2, server-03.company.com -Credential COMPANY\Administrator

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows connecting to multiple servers at once.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "server-04","server-06" |Connect-Rdp -Credential $Credentials

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows passing the computernames over the pipe

maml:description.maml:para: Export an Eventlog from a local or remote computer
This function will export the logname you specify to the folder and filename that you provide. The exported file is in the native format for Event logs.
This function leverages the System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader class to export the log of the local or remote computer.

maml:Description.maml:para: Type the NetBIOS name, an Internet Protocol (IP) address, or the fully qualified domain name of the computer. The default value is the local computer.
This parameter accepts only one computer name at a time. To find event logs or events on multiple computers, use a ForEach statement.
To get events and event logs from remote computers, the firewall port for the event log service must be configured to allow remote access.
Specifies a user account that has permission to perform this action. The default value is the current user.
Export messages from the specified LogName
The full path and filename to where the log should be exported to.
If present the function will list all the logs currently available on the computer.
Type the NetBIOS name, an Internet Protocol (IP) address, or the fully qualified domain name of the computer. The default value is the local computer.
This parameter accepts only one computer name at a time. To find event logs or events on multiple computers, use a ForEach statement.
To get events and event logs from remote computers, the firewall port for the event log service must be configured to allow remote access.
Specifies a user account that has permission to perform this action. The default value is the current user.
The full path and filename to where the log should be exported to.
If present the function will list all the logs currently available on the computer.
Export messages from the specified LogName

maml:alert.maml:para: FunctionName : Export-EventLogs Created by : jspatton Date Coded : 04/30/2012 12:36:12
The folder and filename that you specify will be created on the remote machine.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Export-EventLogs -ComputerName sql -Credential (Get-Credential) -LogName Application -Destination 'C:\LogFiles1\Application.evtx'

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to export the Application log from a computer named SQL and save the file as Application.evtx in a folder called LogFiles. This also shows how to use the Get-Credential cmdlet to pass credentials into the function.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Export-EventLog -ListLog Application HardwareEvents Internet Explorer Key Management Service Media Center

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to list the lognames on the local computer

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Export-EventLog -LogName Application -Destination C:\Logs\App.evtxExport-EventLog -LogName Application -Destination C:\Logs\App.evtx

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to export the Application log on the local computer to a folder on the local computer.

maml:description.maml:para: Get the disk usage of a given path
This function returns the disk usage of a given path

maml:Description.maml:para: The path to check
The path to check

maml:alert.maml:para: FunctionName : Get-DiskUsage Created by : jspatton Date Coded : 03/21/2012 10:29:24
If you don't have access to read the contents of a given folder the function returns 0.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-DiskUsage -Dir c:\
FolderName FolderSize ---------- ---------- C:\dcam 204 C:\DPMLogs 1166251 C:\inetpub 0 C:\PerfLogs 0 C:\Program Files 504195070 C:\Program Files (x86) 2747425666 C:\repository 10294506 C:\SCRATCH 0 C:\scripts 2218148 C:\TEMP 0 C:\Trail 0 C:\Users 16198918163 C:\Windows 18163280116

dev:remarks.maml:para: This shows the basic syntax of the command

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-DiskUsage -Dir c:\ |Sort-Object -Property FolderSize
FolderName FolderSize ---------- ---------- C:\SCRATCH 0 C:\Trail 0 C:\TEMP 0 C:\PerfLogs 0 C:\inetpub 0 C:\dcam 204 C:\DPMLogs 1166251 C:\scripts 2218148 C:\repository 10294506 C:\Program Files 504195070 C:\Program Files (x86) 2747425666 C:\Users 16198918163 C:\Windows 18163345365

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows piping the output through Sort-Object

maml:description.maml:para: Return a list of invalid logon attempts.
This function queries the security log of a given computer and retrieves Event ID 4625, failed logon attempt.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the computer to pull logs from
The name of the Event Log.
You will notice that I have set the LogName to Security, since this particular script was designed to find a specific entry. This can be modified to suit your needs.
The Event ID to return.
You will notice that I have set the EventID to 4625, since this particular script was designed to find those particular entries. This can be modified to suit your needs.
The name of the computer to pull logs from
The Event ID to return.
You will notice that I have set the EventID to 4625, since this particular script was designed to find those particular entries. This can be modified to suit your needs.
The name of the Event Log.
You will notice that I have set the LogName to Security, since this particular script was designed to find a specific entry. This can be modified to suit your needs.

maml:alert.maml:para: ScriptName : Get-InvalidLogonAttempts Created By : jspatton Date Coded : 10/26/2011 11:20:58 ScriptName is used to register events for this script LogName is used to determine which classic log to write to
ErrorCodes 100 = Success 101 = Error 102 = Warning 104 = Information

If you adjust the script to look for event id's other than 4625, you will want to examine the Event Properties. This is similar to viewing the "Friendly" view of an event in the event log. Below are all the properties for Event ID 4625.

00 SubjectUserSid S-1-5-18 01 SubjectUserName NODE1$ 02 SubjectDomainName SOECS 03 SubjectLogonId 0x3e7 04 TargetUserSid S-1-0-0 05 TargetUserName Daniel 06 TargetDomainName NODE1 07 Status 0xc000006d 08 FailureReason %%2313 09 SubStatus 0xc0000064 10 LogonType 10 11 LogonProcessName User32 12 AuthenticationPackageName Negotiate 13 WorkstationName NODE1 14 TransmittedServices - 15 LmPackageName - 16 KeyLength 0 17 ProcessId 0x3278 18 ProcessName C:\Windows\System32\winlogon.exe 19 IpAddress ##.###.###.### 20 IpPort 51144

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-InvalidLogonAttempts -ComputerName Desktop-pc1 -LogName 'Security' -EventID 4625
Message MachineName TimeCreated IpAddress LogonType TargetUserName IpPort ------- ----------- ----------- --------- --------- -------------- ------ An account ... Desktop-pc1... 10/26/2011... ##.###.###... 10 Daniel 62581 An account ... Desktop-pc1... 10/26/2011... ##.###.###... 10 Daniel 11369 An account ... Desktop-pc1... 10/26/2011... ##.###.###... 10 Daniel 47575 An account ... Desktop-pc1... 10/26/2011... ##.###.###... 10 Daniel 51144

dev:remarks.maml:para: This is the basic syntax of the command, the output is returned to stdin.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-InvalidLogonAttempts |Export-Csv -Path .\InvalidLoginAttempts.csv

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows redirecting the output through the Export-CSV command to get a csv file.

maml:description.maml:para: Return a list of mapped network drives on the computer
This function returns a list of mapped network drives from the local or remote computer.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the computer to get the list from.
A credentials object to pass if needed.
The name of the computer to get the list from.
A credentials object to pass if needed.

maml:alert.maml:para: FunctionName : Get-MappedDrives Created by : jspatton Date Coded : 03/20/2012 16:03:52

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-MappedDrives
Caption : V: FreeSpace : 4129467170816 Name : V: ProviderName : \\\\users2.company.com\homedir4\jspatton Size : 10737418240 VolumeName : 236

dev:remarks.maml:para: This is the basic syntax of the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-MappedDrives -ComputerName Desktop-PC01
Caption : U: FreeSpace : 134377222144 Name : U: ProviderName : \\\\people.company.com\i\jspatton Size : 687194767360 VolumeName : IGroup

dev:remarks.maml:para: This syntax shows passing the optional ComputerName parameter. If this is not the local computer and you didn't pass the Credentials object, you will be prompted.

maml:description.maml:para: Return a list of shares without using WMI
This function returns a list of shares using the old net view command. This works well in situations where a fierwall may be blocking access.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the server that has file or print shares
This will be either Print or Disk Print returns printer shares Disk returns file shares
The name of the server that has file or print shares
This will be either Print or Disk Print returns printer shares Disk returns file shares

maml:alert.maml:para: FunctionName : Get-NetShares Created by : jspatton Date Coded : 10/08/2014 11:08:30

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-NetShare -ComputerName server-01 -Type Print
Server Share Path ------ ----- ---- server-01 hp01 \\\\server-01\hp01 server-01 hp02 \\\\server-01\hp02 server-01 hp03 \\\\server-01\hp03

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows the basic usage for this function

maml:description.maml:para: Return a list of services using Non-Standard accounts.
This function returns a list of services from local or remote coputers that have non-standard user accounts for logon credentials.

maml:Description.maml:para: The NetBIOS name of the computer to pull services from.
The DOMAIN\USERNAME of an account with permissions to access services.
This is a pipe (|) seperated list of accounts to filter out of the returned services list.
The NetBIOS name of the computer to pull services from.
The DOMAIN\USERNAME of an account with permissions to access services.
This is a pipe (|) seperated list of accounts to filter out of the returned services list.

maml:alert.maml:para: Powershell may need to be run elevated to run this script. UAC may need to be disabled to run this script.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-NonStandardServiceAccounts
StartName Name DisplayName --------- ---- ----------- .\Jeff Patton MyService My Test Service

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows no parameters provided

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-NonStandardServiceAccounts -Computer dpm -Credentials $Credentials
StartName Name DisplayName --------- ---- ----------- .\MICROSOFT$DPM$Acct MSSQL$MS$DPM2007$ SQL Server (MS$DPM2007$) .\MICROSOFT$DPM$Acct MSSQL$MSDPM2010 SQL Server (MSDPM2010) NT AUTHORITY\NETWORK SERVICE MSSQLServerADHelper100 SQL Active Directory Helper S... NT AUTHORITY\NETWORK SERVICE ReportServer$MSDPM2010 SQL Server Reporting Services... .\MICROSOFT$DPM$Acct SQLAgent$MS$DPM2007$ SQL Server Agent (MS$DPM2007$) .\MICROSOFT$DPM$Acct SQLAgent$MSDPM2010 SQL Server Agent (MSDPM2010)

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows all parameters in use

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-NonStandardServiceAccounts -Computer dpm -Credentials $Credentials ` -Filter "localsystem|NT Authority\LocalService|NT Authority\NetworkService|NT AUTHORITY\NETWORK SERVICE"
StartName Name DisplayName --------- ---- ----------- .\MICROSOFT$DPM$Acct MSSQL$MS$DPM2007$ SQL Server (MS$DPM2007$) .\MICROSOFT$DPM$Acct MSSQL$MSDPM2010 SQL Server (MSDPM2010) .\MICROSOFT$DPM$Acct SQLAgent$MS$DPM2007$ SQL Server Agent (MS$DPM2007$) .\MICROSOFT$DPM$Acct SQLAgent$MSDPM2010 SQL Server Agent (MSDPM2010)

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example uses the Filter parameter to filter out NT AUTHORITY\NETWORK SERVICE account from the preceeding example.
The back-tick (`) was used for readability purposes only.

maml:description.maml:para: Get a list of files open on the server
This function returns a list of files open on a given server. The output is similar to that of the Manage Open Files from the Share and Storage Management console.

maml:Description.maml:para: The NetBIOS or FQDN of the computer
The NetBIOS or FQDN of the computer

maml:alert.maml:para: FunctionName : Get-OpenFiles Created by : Jeff Patton Date Coded : 09/26/2011 13:01:38

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-OpenFiles -ComputerName fs
User Path LockCount ---- ---- --------- User1 F:\Users\User1\Documents\Data\... 0 User2 P:\Public 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows the basic usage of this command.

maml:description.maml:para: Return a list of open sessions
This function returns a list of open session on a given server. The output is similar to that of the Manage Open Sessions dialog in the Share and Storage Management console.

maml:Description.maml:para: This is the FQDN or NetBIOS name of the computer
This is the FQDN or NetBIOS name of the computer

maml:alert.maml:para: FunctionName : Get-OpenSessions Created by : Jeff Patton Date Coded : 09/26/2011 11:35:40

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-OpenSessions -ComputerName fs
User Computer ConnectTime IdleTime ---- -------- ----------- -------- user1 10.10.1.62 1615 1 user2 10.10.1.156 7529 17

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows the basic usage of the command.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the updates waiting to be installed from WSUS
Retrieves the updates that are available to install on the local system

maml:Description.maml:para: Computer or computers to find updates for.
Computer or computers to find updates for.

maml:alert.maml:para: Author: Boe Prox Date Created: 05Mar2011 RPC Dynamic Ports need to be enabled on inbound remote servers.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-PendingUpdates

maml:description.maml:para: Get a log of all printing from a given server.
This function will return a log of all the printing that has occurred on a given print server.

maml:Description.maml:para: The default log for printing on Windows Server 2008 R2 is specified.
The name of your print server.
The name of your print server.
The default log for printing on Windows Server 2008 R2 is specified.

maml:alert.maml:para: The following log will need to be enabled before logs can be generated by the server: "Microsoft-Windows-PrintService/Operational"

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-PrinterLogs -ComputerName ps
Size : 96060 Time : 8/16/2011 5:01:09 PM User : MyAccount Job : 62 Client : \\\\10.133.5.143 Port : Desktop-PC01.company.com Printer : HP-Laser Pages : 1 Document : Microsoft Office Outlook - Memo Style

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows the basic usage of the command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-PrinterLogs -ComputerName ps |Export-Csv -Path .\PrintLogs.csv

dev:remarks.maml:para: This is the syntax that I would see being used the most.

maml:description.maml:para: Return Remote Desktop login attempts

This function returns login attempts from the Microsoft Windows TerminalServices RemoteConnectionManager log. The specific events are logged as EventID 1149, and they are logged whether or not the user actually gets to the desktop.

maml:Description.maml:para: This is the NetBIOS name of the computer to pull events from.
A user account with the ability to retreive these events.
This is the NetBIOS name of the computer to pull events from.
A user account with the ability to retreive these events.

maml:alert.maml:para: The Microsoft-Windows-TerminalServices-RemoteConnectionManager/Operational needs to be enabled The user account supplied in $Credentials needs to have permission to view this log No output is returned if the log is empty.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-RDPLoginEvents -Credentials $Credentials -ComputerName MyPC |Format-Table
SourceNetworkAddress Domain TimeCreated User -------------------- ------ ----------- ---- 192.168.1.1 MyPC... 4/30/2011 8:20:02 AM Administrator... 192.168.1.1 MyPC... 4/28/2011 4:53:01 PM Administrator... 192.168.1.1 MyPC... 4/21/2011 2:01:42 PM Administrator... 192.168.1.1 MyPC... 4/19/2011 11:42:59 AM Administrator... 192.168.1.1 MyPC... 4/19/2011 10:30:52 AM Administrator...

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows piping the output to Format-Table

maml:description.maml:para: Get the serial number (Dell ServiceTag) from Win32_BIOS
An example showing the only parameter.

maml:Description.maml:para: The NetBIOS name of the computer.
The NetBIOS name of the computer.

maml:alert.maml:para: This space intentionally left blank.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-ServiceTag -ComputerName Desktop-01
SerialNumber ------------ 1AB2CD3

maml:description.maml:para: A tail cmdlet for Eventlogs

This function will allow you to tail Windows Event Logs. You specify a Logname for either the original logs, Application, System and Security or the new format for the newer logs Microsoft-Windows-PowerShell/Operational

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify a valid Windows Eventlog name
An integer to show the number of events to start with, the default is 10
Specify a valid Windows Eventlog name
An integer to show the number of events to start with, the default is 10

maml:alert.maml:para: FunctionName : Get-WinEventTail Created by : jspatton Date Coded : 10/09/2014 13:20:22

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-WinEventTail -LogName Application
ProviderName: ESENT
TimeCreated Id LevelDisplayName Message ----------- -- ---------------- ------- 10/9/2014 11:55:51 AM 102 Information svchost (7528) Instance: ... 10/9/2014 11:55:51 AM 105 Information svchost (7528) Instance: ... 10/9/2014 11:55:51 AM 326 Information svchost (7528) Instance: ... 10/9/2014 12:05:49 PM 327 Information svchost (7528) Instance: ... 10/9/2014 12:05:49 PM 103 Information svchost (7528) Instance: ...

maml:description.maml:para: Grant permissions on registry paths
This function allows you to set permissions on registry paths on a computer. Using the parameters you can specify the rights, inheritance and propagation of the rights.

maml:Description.maml:para: A registry path
Username in DOMAIN\User format
Specifies the access control rights that can be applied to registry objects. See http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.security.accesscontrol.registryrights(v=vs.110).aspx
Inheritance flags specify the semantics of inheritance for access control entries (ACEs). See http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.security.accesscontrol.inheritanceflags(v=vs.110).aspx

Specifies how Access Control Entries (ACEs) are propagated to child objects. These flags are significant only if inheritance flags are present. See http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.security.accesscontrol.propagationflags(v=vs.110).aspx
Inheritance flags specify the semantics of inheritance for access control entries (ACEs). See http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.security.accesscontrol.inheritanceflags(v=vs.110).aspx
A registry path
Username in DOMAIN\User format

Specifies how Access Control Entries (ACEs) are propagated to child objects. These flags are significant only if inheritance flags are present. See http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.security.accesscontrol.propagationflags(v=vs.110).aspx
Specifies the access control rights that can be applied to registry objects. See http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.security.accesscontrol.registryrights(v=vs.110).aspx

maml:alert.maml:para: FunctionName : Grant-RegistryPermission Created by : jspatton Date Coded : 01/12/2015 14:53:41

I lifted this almost completely from iheartpowershell's blog, this appears to be the first iteration of this function, I have since found it copied verbatim onto other blogs, so I feel the need to give credit where credit is due.
I modified this function to build the identity from a username, and pass in the identityrefernce object to the rule.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Grant-RegistryPermission -Path HKCU:\Environment\ -Principal DOMAIN\User01 -Rights FullControl
Path Owner Access ---- ----- ------ Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\Registry::... NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM NT AUTHORITY\RESTRICTED Allow ReadK...

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example grants full control to the environment key for user01

maml:description.maml:para: Create a Credential Object
This function creates a new Credential Object for use in Scripts or cmdlets.

maml:Description.maml:para: The username associated with the password
A Password as a SecureString
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
A Password as a SecureString
The username associated with the password
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Credential = New-Credential -Username user1 -Password (ConvertFrom-SecureString "P@ssw0rd" -AsPlainText -Force)

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creating a credential

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new password
This function creates a password using the cryptographic Random Number Generator see the MSDN link for more details.

maml:Description.maml:para: An integer that defines how long the password should be
An integer that defines how many passwords to create
Returns passwords as SecureStrings
A switch that if present will include special characters
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Returns passwords as SecureStrings
An integer that defines how many passwords to create
An integer that defines how long the password should be
A switch that if present will include special characters
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> New-Password -Length 64 -Count 5 -Strong
Password -------- UkQfV)RHwcQ3a)s8Z#QwSCLxlI*y28kEPmcQUVM2HrACf@PxRJDLk4ffge#1m_8j XfAwZOh_lrzLE8NwkSTPs5#LNkW4uZ0Wm_ST5UzERqhY45)HBpN$_@@MxDeLiosW h(BN(y^Gip&pU$KJpAAajgopQyoSbCn41m53mc__wV@q$DY5a$iN&O0fnf9hvO1& tXkFwY_pe(VIFf$R2^bKyKy)D_H6q^Nz7MgSDylXrV2GIkyiFVnvfbd9KENFuHQz &6LPlWRB$#yqD@!IEuJ9JcMTKrsA_t(AbWRGTLx@2Fw__j08n(TGi6wgPE6XlLWg

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates 5 strong passwords that are 64 characters long
